data.text:
Ben: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Brian, have you ever had to cancel an episode, like mid episode because something was going wrong and it was just unrecoverable?

Brian: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Yes. Actually, the one that was the worst that I still released was, ironically enough, the guy that invented the MP3.

Ben: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â [laughs]

Welcome back to episode 33 of Acquired, the show about technology acquisitions and IPOs. Iâm Ben Gilbert.

David: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Iâm David Rosenthal.

Ben: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â And we are your hosts. Today weâve got a great guest with us, Brian McCullough from the Internet History Podcast. We are huge, huge fans of Brianâs podcast here on Acquired, so super, super pumped to have him joining us today. Weâre doing a double episode so youâll be able to hear a version of this episode on Brianâs podcast as well. And today, we will be talking about the valley-shaping acquisition that happened in 2003, of Yahoo acquiring overture.

Now before we go to Brian, hereâs a quick word from this episodeâs sponsor, Silicon Valley Bank:

Silicon Valley Bank is the go-to bank for startup founders when they get funding. Whatâs something that you guys do or offer that most people donât know about?

âYeah. Most people do recognize that we are really good at the early stage and can provide debt financing and other solutions that other financial institutions wonât at that stage. But what people I think lose sight of because weâre so strong at the early stage is the fact that weâre working with something like 50% I think of the number of companies that went public in the innovation economy over the last year. Weâre working with a lot of late-stage companies and putting together very large transactions for big multinational companies that have scaled over the years and folks lose sight of that a little bit.â

Great. Thanks, man.

Now without any further ado, over to you, Brian.

Brian: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Guys, thanks for doing this crossover. So yeah, today weâre going to be talking about an interesting acquisition story â interesting in the sense that itâs not just one company acquiring another because thereâs a huge major third player that comes into the story. But weâre going to talk about Yahoo acquiring GoTo.com which at the time of acquisition was known as Overture.com.

So, to set the acquisition groundwork here, GoTo.com was a company that came out of an incubator in the late 1990s. Incubators were hot during the dot-com era. One of the hot ones â

David: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Whatâs old is new again these days.

Brian: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Exactly. The incubator weâre talking about was called Idealab which was founded by a man probably most of you know by the name of Bill Gross. Idealab generated a couple of different companies: CarsDirect.com, Net Zero (the free ISP, if you remember that, for back in the day), the infamous eToys.com came out of Idealab. But probably the most successful company to be incubated at Idealab was GoTo.com. I believe this was 100% Bill Grossâ brainstorm. What GoTo was, was a glorified search engine where the results of a search were generated not by an algorithm based on accuracy or what youâre searching for necessarily but was actually, the results were generated by bids from advertisers. So if you went to GoTo.com and you searched for flowers, the #1 search result would be brought up, paid for by an advertiser that had bid the most for that ad. So essentially â

David: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Thatâs one that, you know, doing research for this show, is just so crazy to even think about today but there were no organic search results, like everything you saw on GoTo.com and then later in Overture weâll talk about how they shifted their product and business models was an ad. It would be like Google but without the organic search results.

Brian: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Right. I think they might have back-fed some organic search results from somewhere else. They would have had to especially at launch since they wouldnât have had enough advertisers to cover everything. But yeah, itâs basically Google but all ads.

Ben: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â So basically, Google these days, right?

Brian: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Yeah. Believe me, from someone that still owns a business that gets a lot of my business from paid search, I know what youâre talking about. It was controversial especially at the time. I mean, weâre laughing looking back at it now. But this was completely antithetical to everything that people thought search should be. Bill Gross announced and launched GoTo.com at the TED conference in 1998. A funny side listeners to my show know that Iâm associated with TED, Iâve been working with them for the last year or so: they donât mention Bill Gross by name but they do mention when you give a TED talk, not to sell. And Billâs TED talk in 1998 was very controversial within the TED community because it was basically standing up and launching a new product that people were like, âWell, this is not a world-changing product. Youâre just up there selling us on your new startup.â So it sort of, without naming him, they use that as an example of what not to do these days.

Ben: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Much cheaper than renting out Moscone Center yourself.

Brian: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Right. Exactly.

David: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â And not only launching a new product, but a new product that was just ads.

Brian: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Right. Exactly. Itâs not a new product thatâs going to cure malaria or something like that. But one thing we have to say about GoTo is that it was very quickly successful which makes sense because if you think about it, itâs pure advertising. And weâll get to this later on. But the model, Googleâs business model which we now think of as the greatest advertising machine ever created by man, itâs already present in this first version called GoTo.com with obvious caveats. But it was immediately successful in the same way that Googleâs AdWords product was almost immediately successful.

Thereâs a couple things that I need to point out about how GoTo worked. First of all, it was a destination in and of itself. They called it GoTo.com because Bill Gross wanted it to be a shopping destination. It also, as we pointed out, was all ads. And it was pay to play essentially. If you were willing to pay $100 a click, you could be #1 on every single keyword on GoTo.com. As weâll get into later, Google tweaks that model later on. But as I pointed out, it started out as a standalone destination which was not very helpful to Overture/GoToâs business model because there were already existing properties that got way more traffic: Yahoo, AOL, Excite, places like that. So even though GoTo.com was successful, it was not successful enough because it wasnât scaling.

So, Bill Gross has the brilliant idea of syndicating the ad model of GoTo. This is when they changed the name to Overture because Overture obviously means making an introduction. GoTo/Overture begins cutting deals with every major search portal in about 1999 to 2000 including AOL, Yahoo, Excite, you name it. What started to happen is in your normal Yahoo or AOL search results, you would see 2, 3, maybe 4 Overture results at the top. Those would be the same ones that you would see if you went to GoTo/Overture, but they were just the little syndicated paid links now at the top. This model was unbelievably successful, and it was successful at a time when major search portals needed some serious cashflow because by 2000 into 2001, the dot-com bubble is bursting. And that means that a lot of the companies that places like Yahoo were piggybacking on top of to make their money to sell the display ads that were running against their portal pages and their search results were going out of business. Yahoo especially â I was just researching this for my book â in 2001, I believe the first quarter of 2001, they suddenly to announce that their guidance for the quarter is going to be lower by 25%. About a month later, they come back and the say, âYou know what, weâre going to guide down another 25%. So imagine this is how bad it is in 2001 that twice a public company has to lower guidance by 25% within the same quarter.

Ben: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Wow.

David: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â That's unimaginable today.

Brian: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Well, we hope so.

David: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â When people talk about how todayâs entrepreneurs havenât lived through the hard times, this is what theyâre talking about.

Brian: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Right. I got some more great numbers for you. Yahoo â weâll use Yahoo as an example because theyâre going to come into the story now â their market cap at its peak was 128 billion. By January of 2001, their stock price had gone down from 118 to 4.05. The market cap had gone down from 128 billion to 11 billion. Thatâs 92% down from its high. So when people talk about the carnage of the dot-com bubble bursting of the nuclear winter like we call it, thatâs what weâre talking about â where sales are just evaporating overnight, your high-flying market cap is eviscerated.

Ben: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Wow.

David: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Incredible. This is the same time on our Amazon IPO episode that Tom was talking about when everybody was hit by this. Amazon, eBay, even the companies that end up surviving and thriving to today were trading for pennies of what they once had been.

Brian: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Well, into this crazy time period where everybodyâs losing money, all these dot-com companies are going away. Because thatâs whatâs exactly happening to Yahoo, is that they had ridden the Pets.com. the Toys.com, the iVillage.com â all these dot-coms that were willing to spend, spend, spend all their VC money in order to stand out from the crowd and hopefully have a flashy IPO. Theyâre gone. So overnight, Yahoo loses somewhere around 60% of its advertising base. Into this breach steps Overture and immediately, as I said, is super successful for its partners. Basically, by 2001 all of the profits that Yahoo is making is from its search deal with Overture.

David: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Yeah. We sort of made fun of GoTo at the beginning of the episode, but we shouldnât shortchange the company and Bill Gross here. I mean, it is brilliant, what they do from a business perspective. They invented the paid search model and then had the insight when they didnât have enough traffic themselves as a destination site to marry that model with traffic, search traffic that other portals had. I mean, these are really two brilliant observations from a business standpoint that Bill Gross and Overture had.

Brian: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â So I'm going to quickly jump to the acquisition that weâre talking about and then I'm going to cycle back to the third player that weâre talking about here. Essentially, itâs obvious to anyone listening to the story that Yahoo, if theyâre making all of their money from this deal with Overture, maybe wants to acquire the company that is suddenly responsible for most of their revenue. So in mid-2003, negotiations with Overture bear fruit and Yahoo agrees to buy Overture for $1.4 billion which was actually 25% less than Overture was asking for. So I want to make a quick point here why is Overture willing to sell on the cheap. Well, if you think about it, theyâre in an unsustainable situation. Theyâre making everybody tons of money. But they donât own any of the properties that are getting the traffic themselves. So theyâre operating a business that is incredibly reliant on their partners if they were to lose, say, a Yahoo or an MSN or an AOL, which they do, weâll talk about in a second. If they lose any of those major partnerships, theyâre basically out of the game.

So the reason that Yahoo is able to come in and purchase Overture on the cheap is that Yahoo knows that they sort of have Overture over a barrel. Yahoo is willing to pay a lot because it wants to lock down that revenue. But it's worth pointing out that for all the money that Overture was making, people, it was basically in an untenable situation and needed to be acquired by somebody.

Ben: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â So Brian, do you think that thatâs always a bad strategy to kind of have all of your potential exits be partners that are direct competitors?

Brian: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â I think that obviously doesnât put you in a good negotiating situation because your acquirer can basically say to you âWeâre willing to buy you and save your life, and if we walk away from this deal, weâre killing you.â

Ben: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Right.

Brian: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â So itâs âLet us save you or weâre going to kill you.â Thatâs not a great negotiation position to be.

David: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Yeah. At the same time though, it was still a $1.4 billion deal, like thatâs a lot of money, especially for a company that was only founded 5 years earlier and youâre in the middle of the carnage of the tech bubble.

Brian: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Absolutely.

David: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Yahooâs market cap was at that point, would you say like $11 billion-ish or itâs 10$?

Brian: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Yeah. Around the $10 billion.

David: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Yeah. Thatâs more than 10% of their market cap.

Brian: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â I would say that in this era, the two big acquisitions that make people stand up and take notice and be like âHey, maybe the internet space isnât deadâ was this acquisition and then the PayPal acquisition.

Ben: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â To be fair, this was a 15% bump over where Overture was currently trading.

Brian: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Right. Because Overture was a public company at that point. I think we forgot to point that out.

All right. So I want to smash cut now over to the third player in the story, which is Google because if youâre listening to this, youâre thinking, well, what weâre talking about is basically Googleâs business model which is paid search. What people forget about the Google story is that Google did not have a revenue model for a very long time. Their original business model when they took their money from Sequoia and Kleiner Perkins was basically to syndicate search results. So again, weâre in an era where there are 7 or 8 major âsearchâ players, and I'm saying search in quotes because a lot of them werenât doing real search. They were more portals. But search was a component of what the portals were offering people. So, Googleâs original business model was to basically offer the search results to these 7 or 8 players and get licensing deals for providing the service.

David: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Whatâs crazy, you know, to think about how different the world was back then. I could be wrong on this but I'm pretty sure that the way Google did that was through the Google search appliance which was actually a piece of hardware that their partners would install in their data centers. Itâs so hard to imagine today.

Brian: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Yeah. For fans of Silicon Valley, they made a box. So now if youâre Google in 2001 and youâre sort of hunting around for a business model. Because really, that licensing, your search results to 7 or 8 players doesnât really scale very well. Itâs a decent business. Itâs not a multibillion dollar business. If youâre Google in 2001, youâre looking over at Overture and youâre seeing that Overture is having incredible success in what is essentially your space, and theyâre doing it via a business model that is pretty obvious.

As an example, 2001 is the first year that Google actually is profitable. In 2001, its revenues were $85 million. In that same year, Overture had revenue of 288 million. At that point, Overture was growing faster, was growing its revenues faster. So, Google does what is the obvious thing in retrospect and probably even at the time, they say, âHey, maybe letâs give this Overture model a try.â The original version of AdWords that Google launched was basically CPM. They were still text-based ads and they were put at the top of search results. But they were glorified banner ads even though they were text. Basically, advertisers paid per thousand viewers for the ads that showed up.

One thing that we havenât pointed out is that Overture has pioneered paying per click CPC, which advertisers love because itâs much easier to measure results versus measuring on a CPM basis. So, Google first experiments by doing AdWords at the top and Ford or Coke or whoever would pay by the thousand viewers. Then they start to introduce what overture is doing. So theyâre putting search results on a cost per click basis at the top and then later on the side as weâre more familiar with. But they do two things that Overture hadnât done. Two huge innovations. Number one, Overture always had editors. So if you submitted an ad to Overture and you say âI want to advertise for flowers,â they would have to make sure that you really were a flower business, they would have to make sure that the ad was copacetic. They even had to make sure. You know, theyâd approve your text and all those things. Well, we know Google as the company of engineers where thereâs no problem that canât be solved by math and some decent engineering. So they donât want to do this editorial stuff and so they create an automated system. Whereas with Overture, you would submit your ad and it would take a day or two for the ad to go live. Google created an automated system where you would bid on keywords, submit your ad and the algorithms would make sure that the ads were cool and your ad would be running within the hour.

They also targeted small advertisers. Overture was still in this sort of display ad business or the traditional ad business where youâre chasing big brand advertisers. And Google said, âHey, if youâve got a credit card, I donât care who you are. Throw $50 at us and you can run some ads and letâs see if this works for you.â So Google goes after small advertisers and basically creates the modern search advertising marketplace that weâre familiar with today.

Ben: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â By going there, after those small advertisers, they really created a new market too because if youâre Coke, you can go deploy $100 million on billboards around the market and you can buy these brand advertisements. But if youâre using search ads and you have metrics on the number of people clicking through for the first time, thereâs a real market for direct response advertising and not just brand awareness ads.

Brian: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Right. Itâs a different type of advertiser where itâs more direct response advertising as opposed to brand advertising which traditionally still is in the display business as opposed to the search business. Thatâs even true to this day to a large extent.

So the second key innovation is itâs not just pay-to-play. You canât go into a keyword, be willing to pay $100 per click and be guaranteed at the top. Google of course being Google, again, wants to have this sense that âHey, itâs a win-win-win for everybody. We want to have the most relevant adsâ so that the ads will almost be useful to a searcher, not an annoyance to a searcher. So, they introduce this key innovation of the click response rates affect the bidding process for the keyword. So itâs not just the person that pays the highest gets the top. Itâs some combination of the person willing to pay the highest and the person whose ads gets clicked on the most and thus making that ad probably the most relevant.

David: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Yeah. And weâll circle back and talk more about this later in the episode in the analysis. But this is a super key point for two reasons. One, that allows Google through their system to actually optimize revenue, not just the amount of money that people would spend on a given auction but the way that the revenue will be the amount of money spent on a CPC ad times the number of people who click. So by optimizing for also people who click, they optimize revenue. Then the second key point is that this is a really hard math problem and hard data problem that Google is going to need a lot of engineering and technology to solve, and weâll see that come back later.

Brian: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Right. I think that itâs worth underlining that. Google actually is able to make more money by this model because by making it more relevant, if you do the math and itâs too complicated to go into here, but it actually ends up making Google more money because theyâre getting more money from the ads that are clicked on the most.

Ben: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Yeah. And Brian, is this the point that Google introduces that other innovation of lowering the price of the bid to just above the second highest bidder?

Brian: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Yes. In the Overture model, if you were willing to pay 50 cents and the number two bidder was willing to pay 10 cents, when you got clicked on, you still pay that 50 cents which sounds crazy, and it was. So one of the things that really won people over from Overture to Googleâs AdWords â and I can speak from experience because I was one of these advertisers at the time â was okay, on Googleâs model, if I pay 50 cents, my competitor bids 10. If they click on my ad, Iâm only paying 11 cents. Iâm only paying just over what the second was bidding. And I donât have to do anything to do that. Itâs automatically done for me.

Ben: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Which really, I mean, that starts to feel like Google being a real enduring company, right? Making these decisions that really bring the marketplace efficiency in line with where the market actually is and not just saying this is a âsmash and grab job for cash nowâ but really we want to have this advertiser relationship for a long time.

Brian: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Indeed. So let me pick up the story. Itâs February of 2002 that the modern AdWords as we know it with the change to cost-per-click and with this quality score on ads is introduced, February of 2002. And one of the executives that is brought in to lead the ad team at this point is a young lady by the name of Sheryl Sandberg. And Sheryl as we know basically â

David: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â I feel like Iâve heard of her somewhere.

Brian: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Makes her early career by the success of AdWords. But letâs go back to the Yahoo-Overture-Google triangle here. Because Yahoo had a preexisting relationship with Google. Google had been since 2002 providing the search results for Yahoo. People always forget this. Yahoo was never technically a search engine. It started out as a human power directory and through the mid to late â90s, that was their differentiator. Search engines just didnât really work very well. And so Yahoo sort of made its name by saying if you come to us, go through our directory. Youâre going to find what you want to look for because weâve taken the time like actual human beings taking the time to sort this out for you.

Ben: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â And they were touting the fact that they were a media company and their primary revenue driver at that point or at least a little before was the banner ads that they were putting on their own first party media content, right?

Brian: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â They did a lot of things to try to introduce e-commerce. There was Yahoo Shops and things like that. But yeah, still 80% of their business as we discussed were people buying banner ads, especially the dot-com companies buying banner ads.

So, Yahoo already has this preexisting relationship with Google. And Google has seen that Overture has created this incredible business by syndicating these paid search results. So, around 2002, Google starts to do the same thing. Remember, theyâre still these multiple players. Still AOL is the biggest player at this point. Yahoo is the biggest portal at this point.

And so Google is starting to shop around this idea that âHey, we can syndicate our ad words in the same way that Overture does,â and so the first person that they go to to try to cut a deal like this is Yahoo who they have this pretty existing relationship with. And so that is really when Yahoo starts to get the idea of maybe it itself needs to get into the search game. As weâre saying, search was not their business. They were basically selling ads against eyeball, thus were calling them portal sites.

But an interesting thing is, is that since Yahoo and Google have this relationship, Yahoo is able to take a look at Googleâs internals. So in the same way that it can see on its bottom line all the money that itâs making with Overture, it can see when Google is similarly having incredible success syndicating its AdWords ads, the big deal that Google is able to pull off is when it steals AOL from Overture. Overture had been providing those paid links at the top of AOL search results. Google swoops in and steals that business from Overture to the tune of about $100 million, at least that was the deal in guaranteed revenue that they had to offer to AOL. But again, because Yahoo has this relationship with Google, it can see that the AOL deal is instantaneously extremely successful for Google. This is around the same time if you guys might remember, the summer of 2002 that Yahoo first tries to buy Google. Before they make the overture to Overture, they try to buy Google for $3 billion and are rebuffed. Which is interesting because at that point, Googleâs revenue was probably only about $240 million a year and Yahooâs yearly revenue was $837 million. Itâs starting to recover in this period from the dot-com bust. A CEO by the name of Terry Semel comes in and basically doubles down on the display advertising business and turning Yahoo into a media destination.

So Yahooâs stock price was only about $7 a share. So the $5 billion purchase price that Google wanted â Yahoo is offering 3 billion, Google wants 5 billion â would essentially have meant that Yahoo was going to spend basically its entire market cap to swing the deal. It definitely would not have been a merger of equals. It would have been basically Google taking over Yahoo by proxy.

Ben: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Wow.

Brian: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â So, Yahoo does not get to buy Google. And so in its mind it has to do the next best thing. Overture is obviously the business model that Google has copied and is having success with. So, why canât Yahoo just go ahead, buy Overture, buy another company, get into the search game and basically replicate the business model that Google is having success with, that it has copied from Overture.

David: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Sounds great. What could go wrong?

Brian: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â What could go wrong? And so, this is essentially what happens. The first thing that Yahoo purchases is Inktomi. So that gives them what a lot of people at the time thought was a search engine that was equivalent in quality to Google or at least the second best search engine on the planet at that point. So they buy Inktomi in late 2002 at a relative bargain. The acquisition was 257 million. So then on top of that, they turned around and paid the $1.4 billion for the search ad pioneer, Overture. So those are two big acquisitions. Remember Yahooâs market cap is under 10 billion at that point. But itâs a lot less than what Google had been asking for, right?

Ben: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Right.

Brian: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â So, the acquisition goes through and itâs immediately a big win for Yahoo because overnight, acquiring Overture triples Yahooâs profit. In 2004, its revenue doubled and the profit more than tripled by bring Overtureâs search ad business in-house. It actually immediately has a positive impact on Yahooâs stock which goes from $16 a share the day that the Overture deal was announced to $37 a share about a year later. And thereâs an ironic quote from Terry Semel around the acquisition where he says, âWe got into search to change the game.â Itâs ironic because most of us thought that Yahoo was a search engine but as weâre discussing, in reality they never were.

So, Yahooâs plan here is to integrate these two things: to bring the search engine house, to marry it to Overtureâs existing paid search business. And bam! They can replicate everything that Google has rapidly seeing success with. There was precedence for this because remember, Google used to be the search results for Yahoo. So basically, you swap out Inktomi. That's relatively simple.

Ben: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Seems reasonable.

Brian: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Right. The problem was integrating the Overture search ads business. If youâre Yahoo and your existing business for your entire life is this display ad network where youâve got hundreds of salesmen and basically, you had been in the game for a long time of just getting eyeballs to your site. People coming for horoscopes, for maps, for checking your email and things like that. All of a sudden, you basically have to upend the culture of the company and say weâre in this engineering-based search business. And it turns out that that was the problem of the acquisition that it was a huge, on some level, technical headache to integrate to the Overture business into Yahoo but more than anything else, it was a cultural headache, a cultural clash of trying to change Yahooâs business model basically midstream.

Ben: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â So many thoughts but holding my tongue for analysis.

Brian: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Let me wrap this up then and explain why the acquisition we can say was not entirely successful. They bring in Overture and the Overture team conflicts with the existing Yahoo engineering team, the Overture business model conflicts with the existing Yahoo display ad business model, people donât get along, people arenât executing; or letâs just say that different teams are moving in different directions, not everyoneâs rowing the boat in the same way. At some point in 2005, they fire the original Overture CEO that was brought in with the acquisition and hereâs another name that you might recognize. Guess who they bring in to try to save the integration of the Overture business?

David: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â A hint. We did an episode about his company being acquired.

Brian: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â It was a young gentleman by the name of Jeff.

David: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Weiner.

Brian: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Who we now are more familiar with as the LinkedIn CEO. And Weiner did have success integrating the Inktomi search, just swapping them out that had been done before. But he had an incredibly difficult time putting the Overture business together with the search business. There was this huge project called Project Panama that Yahoo promised for years and years and years would launch and would be just as easy to use as AdWords. All you had to have was a credit card, will have the automated system, will do the ad scoring so that weâre going to reward people for the most times they clicked on the ad relevance, that sort of thing. Basically, everything that Google had done with AdWords. Project Panama was supposed to do the same thing, only better of course. But they never really pulled that off. I believe that Project Panama was announced in late 2004 or early 2005.
